28.text:
Welcome to Fielldsports Britain:  "Coming
up - The invisible man - we learn how to apply

34.text:
army sniper secrets to hunting situations.
We've got the regulars, Hunting YouTube,.NewsStump

42.text:
First, Andy Crow is making light work of rabbits,
light work get it!

50.text:
The last time we tried to go rabbiting with
Messers Dom and Crow it all went a bit Pete

55.text:
Tong -- When we arrived Crow stuffed his knee
up by falling out of a tractor -- He refused

61.text:
to go to hospital and despite the pain went
rabbiting. We saw 2 rabbits all night which

67.text:
is why that outing never made it onto the
programme. -- 6 months later we're back, Crow's

72.text:
leg is still rubbish but when he's got a new
chariot like this green mean machine it helps

79.text:
Crow is not the only one with a shiny toy
although he could certainly do with a new

83.text:
buggy...Dom 
has made some changes to his Anschutz...

91.text:
"I found it too long, especially when I shoot
from the vehicle to comfortably get in and

96.text:
out of the truck window and speaking to Chris
Blackburn of UKGunworks we came up with the

103.text:
idea of what difference will it make, what
I didn't want was to compromise the performance

107.text:
of the rifle just for the sake of getting
something that was a bit shorter and a bit

110.text:
more wealdy and he thought it would make for
an interesting experiment. There is a lot

114.text:
of different barrel lengths available on a
rimfire, actually how much difference does

119.text:
it make? So we went to the range with an angle
grinder , with a chronograph, with a load

126.text:
of ammunition and we've set about reducing
it and measuring it and seeing how it performed.

132.text:
The results of which, we will be writing about
in an upcoming issue of the magazine but as

137.text:
you can see, there is no going back, you cant
really stick it back on once its done, so

141.text:
here it is in its new, improved Carbine form
and we are going to give it a go tonight on

146.text:
the Bunnies!
So with a wheezing buggy, a stumpy rifle and

149.text:
a Crow with a peg leg the dream team head
off on the look out for the bunnies.

155.text:
Once again the pressure is on Dom to deliver
-Crow doesn't like to let opportunities slip

159.text:
away -- but some bunnies just don't do what
they're supposed to.

169.text:
Dom is finding the rabbits, but a miss means
Crow takes over for a field or two.

184.text:
They're all within the typical range for a
.17HMR. But then he shoots this rabbit at

189.text:
more than 100 yards. The wind is critical
in this situation. It's a still night, otherwise

196.text:
The .17HMR has become much more popular recently,
its got a better range, faster, flatter, lots

203.text:
of positive things frangible bullets, less
chance of ricochets etc, etc.But it does have

208.text:
a bit of an Achilles heel in windy conditions
- Andy talk us through it:;

214.text:
You can be along a hedgerow, there will be
no wind at all,you smack one rabbit, then

218.text:
you go to one about 70-80 yards out in the
field, there might be wind out there and it

223.text:
just blows it off and anyone who has got one
will know that. Close range, out to say 50-60

228.text:
Yards you don't get much movement, you will
get some but not a lot.

232.text:
Its horses for courses though, isn't it because
some people say, you know , .22;s a better

236.text:
round and some people swear by the .17, each
of them have certain things that they are

241.text:
really good at and certain things that you
have to compromise on. So, in an ideal world,

245.text:
you would have one of each in your gun safe
but realistically , for most of us, it is

251.text:
Yes, the .17, I swear by it, I really do,
I love it. I think its a good round, its a

256.text:
The site of the battery and jump leads in
the back doesn't inspire confidence - but

261.text:
the buggy keeps chugging along and the bunny
bag is growing -- half way though the night

266.text:
we change lamps -- no real reason, it's just
to explore the merits of each -- certainly,

270.text:
for Dom, the beam of the Nightmaster means
he can pinpoint that rabbit straight away.

275.text:
We have been using the taclight which is a
big favourite of Andy and of Roy, it gives

279.text:
a massive range and a very tightly focused
beam. It gives an impressive performance for

286.text:
a compact torch , really easy to use and once
you've found the light beam through the scope,

290.text:
you have found the rabbit because it is such
a narrow beam you know that is where it is

293.text:
going to be. For scanning large grass fields,
like we have been doing tonight, the limitation

298.text:
is that because it is such a narrow beam it
is easy to miss stuff, especially when it

302.text:
is sitting tight in quite long grass or in
the crops. We also switched over to the more

309.text:
traditional light force lamp, which is what
I use when I started lamping, Andy has used

313.text:
this for years and years and years and it
is absolutely brilliant for scanning. Its

317.text:
got a very very very wide beam, not quite
so much reach as the taclight but good for

322.text:
covering large distances. What I noticed in
comparison to the taclight was you have to

329.text:
recalibrate, to keep much more of a focus
on where the rabbit is because you cant just

334.text:
rely on there's a red light, there's a rabbit
because its covering so much more distance.

339.text:
But both are very good but I have to say I
really like the light force type of lamp.

345.text:
Really really good for this type of thing,
for swinging around a field and seeing whats

350.text:
what but I can see why the modern LED lights
have become so popular. They give remarkable

367.text:
Considering we were only out for an hour-and-a-half,
we haven't done too badly, with 50 rabbits,

373.text: relieving a bit of pressure off the crops.

375.text:
This time last year we were way behind. The
Rape was probably two inches in the good places

382.text:
and wasn't even thinking about flowering and
this year. well, ..

386.text:
We shot in this exact same field, last year,
well, a month later than now and it was virtually

392.text:
It wasn't even coming in flower, it was coming
but it wasn't in flower and the field next

398.text:
door, that's probably four foot tall. Its
had two growth regulators on it, its still

403.text:
about four foot tall and full flower. Yes,
like I say, I'm really looking forward to

413.text:
this summers harvest. I think it is going
to be a good one.

416.text:
Stumpy, Limpy and Wheezy did OK tonight --bit
of a miracle really !

422.text:
Thank you Andy for that piece about lights,
now somebody else tripping the light fantastic.

425.text:
Its David on the Fieldsports Channel News
Stump!

431.text:
This is Fieldsports Channel News:
When US TV host Ellen DeGeneres joined a long

440.text:
line of unqualified people to speak out against
seal hunting, the Inuit hunters of Canada

446.text:
and Alaska hit back -- with 'sealfies'.
They have posted hundreds of photos, known

452.text:
has "sealfies," showing off their seal skin
fashion. She has given money to the Humane

457.text:
Society of the United States, one of the most
prominent critics of Canada's seal hunt.

464.text:
Have you ever seen a roosting fox ? When Chris
Pritchard took his girfriend shooting he spotted

468.text:
a fox 20ft up a tree. It was the work of moments
for him to take the gun from the girl and

473.text: shoot it. It was on the top right branch.

477.text:
Boring but important:There is another petition
to allow handguns. It calls on the UK Government

483.text:
to amend the Firearms Acts to allow the ownership
and use of .22 calibre rimfire pistols for

489.text:
competitive sporting purposes in England,
Wales and Scotland. Visit firearmsuk.org/unity

498.text:
Conservative prime minister David Cameron
did not allow a partial repeal of the ban

502.text:
on hunting with hounds last week. Pressure
from his anti-hunting deputy prime minister

507.text:
Nick Clegg, led Cameron to drop plans to allow
more than two hounds to flush animals including

512.text:
foxes, hares and mice. Rabbits and rats are
not affected by the hunting ban. However,

518.text:
Ministers want to issue a "call for evidence"
on how to control foxes and other vermim who

522.text:
are feeding on livestock in upland areas,
so there may still be a vote.

528.text:
Alaskan law makers have come under fire for
banning something that doesn't even happen.

532.text:
They have made it illegal to deploy drones
for hunting purposes. Alaska Wildlife Troopers

538.text:
admit they have no evidence of drone-assisted
hunting.

541.text:
Poachers are shooting storks in Malta - and
their shots have been captured on film.

547.text:
The birds belonged to a flock of 13 storks
which are being monitored by local animal

550.text:
rights groups. Police were unable to find
either the dead storks nor the men who killed

557.text:
Australia has rejected a plan to offer crocodile
trophy hunting.The Australian government said

562.text:
the suggested hunting of around 50 saltwater
crocs across the Northern Territory wouldn't

567.text:
be appropriate, even though 500 salties are
culled in the region every year. The plan

572.text:
was thrown out by Australia's environment
minister, called Greg Hunt.

579.text:
And finally
An American police officer has uploaded a

582.text:
film of him rescuing a frightened fawn tangled
in a mesh of Christmas lights. New York state

589.text:
cop Kevin Sweet cut the lights away with a
knife. is now known as the "deer hero" in

593.text:
his local station and fellow officers have
taped a picture of a deer onto his mailbox.

600.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Channel
News. Stalking the stories, fishing for facts.

612.text:
Thank you David. Next up , lets see what you
lot have been up to. It is Hallo Charlie.

620.text:
Here is what the world is up to this week.
Hello Charlie, me and shaggy here, just going

628.text:
out, doing a little filming for my next piece
for The Shooting Times and I've just been

633.text:
watching the channel this week. Whats all
this about me not smiling! There is an art

635.text:
to looking grumpy and being happy within.
So if you don't know what a Whitehead smile

642.text: looks like, here we go. Happy days.

645.text:
Hallo Charlie! Last day of the Roe Season,
I've just had this lovely culled Roe Doe.

651.text:
She had to be taken because she had a bit
of a bad leg, so she had to go.

656.text:
Hallo Charlie! Bill from Arizona, fishing
in Florida

660.text:
Send us your own Hallo Charlie. Film yourself
on your mobile phone. Just a sentence saying

664.text:
Hallo Charlie, who you are and what you are
up to. Then share it or email it via youtube,facebook,dropbox

668.text: or you send it, you name it to Charlie'fieldsportschannel.tv.

673.text: Please keep those Hallo Charlies coming.

676.text:
.
"Now, we meet a man who's going to show us

678.text: what it really takes to blend into the background"

682.text:
We've done stories about camouflage before
-- some of it serious -- some of it not so

686.text: serious . Oh - where is he now?

690.text:
Today we are not out to knock camo but show
that, with a bit of thought and attention

695.text:
to detail, something we know little about
at Fieldsports Channel Towers, you can just

704.text:
To prove just how effective it can be, hidden
somewhere in this shot is survival expert

709.text:
Dave Roaf with his rifle. Can you spot him?
- a few more seconds........and reveal yourself

729.text:
Dave runs Woodoak Wilderness in Surrey where
anyone who wants to look without being seen

735.text:
lts important not just to be hidden from the
actual quarry that we are hunting but also

740.text:
from all its other locations. You could be
stalking a rabbit or a rat but its the blackbird

745.text:
who gives you away. The moment the blackbird
sees you ,he is shouting at the top of his

750.text:
beak that you're there, you're danger. So
the animals know the other animals call signs

756.text:
Dave has a dozen different ghille suits -- something
for every occasion. But they'll need fine

761.text:
tuning with fresh foliage when a location
has been selected -- drooping is not a good

767.text: look... So what are the basics Dave?

769.text:
The principals of camouflage concealment can
be covered under the simple five S's and the

774.text:
M. The five S's stand for shape, shine, shadow
silhouette and sound and the M is movement

781.text:
or sudden movement. There are a couple of
other S's that I like to add to the list.

785.text:
One of them is statue, knowing when to freeze
and the other one is smell. You need to make

791.text:
sure you don't put any aftershave on in the
morning when you go on to the shoot. But,

796.text:
your camouflage needs to be appropriate to
the environment that you are operating in.

800.text:
It also needs to be appropriate to the weather
environment. There is nothing worse than being

805.text:
all camouflaged up and the sun comes out and
all you do is sweat bucket after bucket after

810.text:
bucket and the other thing is, on a cold day,
if you have not got the layers there you try

815.text:
and hold a steady shot when you are shivering,
you are just not going to take the meat home.

821.text:
Next week, we'll see Dave put his Ghille suit
together but today he showing us how to conceal

825.text:
your rifle. For demo purposes he's using an
unloaded airsoft replica of the British Army

833.text:
If you wanted to be really fussy about the
camouflage. If you take a look at the end

837.text:
of the muzzle of this rifle, its a perfect
round black dot. That will give you away if

843.text:
you have got an observer looking . The trick
is to drape a piece of cloth, a small, light

848.text:
weight piece of cloth over the front and tie
it on at this point. When you pull the shot

852.text:
the air being expelled from the barrel by
the projectile will actually lift the flap

857.text:
up, the projectile will flop and then it will
drop back down again. So that will cover up

862.text:
that little telltale sign. And its little
things like that, attention to detail that

867.text:
will get you spotted. When camouflaging up
your barrel, you need to bare in mind that

872.text:
if you over-camouflage it you will break the
sight line from your scope. So you need to

876.text:
make sure that whatever camouflage is on the
sides and the bottom , that you keep a relatively

880.text:
clear area in the front. There is no point
in having a perfectly camouflaged rifle and

885.text:
you cant see out of it. I always keep a range
of bands or rubber bands as they are called

895.text:
on my rifles, they just helps me to attach
all the necessary netting and foliage that

900.text:
I need. To stop the lens from being a perfect
round circle just take your netting over the

906.text:
top of it, apply the band, pull it tight.
It will blur the vision fractionally but not

913.text:
enough to not make you be able to see through
it. Here is the critical point. Your working

920.text:
parts on a rifle, your cocking handle. You
don't want to cover them over. There is one

925.text:
thing to take a shot. If it is all covered
over, that's it. You will make more movement

929.text:
trying to reload. So keep these areas clear.
Once you are actually in position, your actual

935.text:
camouflage, your hat, your veil and your ghille
suit will cover most of this. So this doesn't

940.text:
need to be camouflaged. Right, that is a basic
camouflage, very quick. Its called a hasty

949.text:
camouflage but its enough. All I am trying
to do is break up the straight lines of the

954.text:
scope and the barrel. Looking from this side
it doesn't look much. But once you start to

959.text:
look at it straight on it becomes another
bush.

963.text:
Dave gets paid for playing hide and seek,
as well as hunting and witnessing some wonderful

967.text:
wildlife moments. He is hired in to carry
out covert surveillance operations, like recording

973.text:
flytippers in the act - and inadvertently
catching human beings in the act too.

980.text:
Far too many and probably inappropriate to
discuss.

983.text:
And, incredibly, outdoor antics are not reserved
for the warmer times of the year.

988.text:
Surprisingly not, its not seasonal. In the
winter there are less stinging nettles.

995.text:
The original Invisible Man was a book of science
fiction by HG Wells published in 1897. A scientist

1000.text:
called Griffin invents a way to change a body's
refractive index to that of air so that it

1004.text:
absorbs and reflects no light. He successfully
carries out this procedure on himself, but

1008.text:
fails in his attempt to reverse the procedure.
Find out if Woodoak Wilderness can do the

1013.text: same for you -- go to Woodoak.co.uk

1017.text:
Now for the wider world of hunting and shooting
on YouTube. It is Hunting YouTube.

1027.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting and shooting videos that

1031.text:
Jonathan McGee is putting out a web series
about stalking in Hampshire in the south of

1035.text:
England with Charly Green of Shavegreen Shooting
Services. Charly sends me ' Passion for Deer

1040.text:
- Part 1 of 6' and I am delighted to showcase
it.

1043.text:
While British cameramen are concentrating
on lovely dappled light and calm professional

1047.text:
stalkers, the American version is this. The
bull elk charges the bow hunter in a video

1052.text: moment that could be sponsored by Andrex.

1054.text:
More from the USA. Viewer Jacob Fredsted sends
in 'Little girl experiences buck fever for

1060.text:
the first time'. Like a 21st century Judy
Garland, she is wonderfully cute and, on advice

1065.text:
from a couple of professional mums, I don't
doubt that it's real, too.

1069.text:
Now a couple of predator films form the USA.
Eastern Coyote Hunting with AR-15 has the

1076.text:
And Realtree brings out its film about predator
hunting in the open country of Arizona. They

1081.text:
shoot a running coyote, and then they set
about finding it.

1084.text:
A1Decoy is out after wild geese in Aberdeenshire.
Despite the proximity of an RSPB reserve (there

1090.text:
was a time the presence of the RSPB was a
guarantee of good shooting), they do well.

1094.text:
Moving south, SafariHuntingUK is decoying
pigeons in Yorkshire. It takes nearly two

1099.text:
minutes to get to the action and the intro
is a bit heavy on the word 'beautiful' -- hey

1103.text:
- we can see it's beautiful -- you don't need
to say it -- but hang in there. There's a

1107.text: good story about pigeon shooting coming up.

1109.text:
And finally hound sports. This is a trailer
for a folksy TV show but if it is anything

1114.text:
to go by, the show should be good. One man,
his mule and a pack of hounds are after mountain

1120.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you are missing the fishing films

1124.text:
and the airgun films, watch our new shows,
AirHeads and Fishing Britain. If you have

1128.text:
a YouTube film you would like us to pop in
to the weekly top eight, send it in via YouTube

1132.text: or email me the link charlie@fieldsportschannel.tv

1134.text:
Well if you didn't like any of those and you
still want to sit and watch telly, why not

1142.text:
Airheads is out on Thursday the 3rd of April
and we're focusing on the best baits- James

1146.text:
Marchington turns his back garden into a test
facility and discovers 8 out of 10 crows prefer...well

1153.text:
you'll have to watch to find out... Click
on the link on the screen to see all the AirHeads

1157.text:
series so far.
And click on the link on the screen for Fishing

1161.text:
Britain this week. We spend a sunny afternoon
with internet angling sensations Carl and

1166.text:
Alex, fishing for a mixed bag of species and
conversation. We reel in large carp, large

1172.text:
tench, perch, rudd and a mighty gudgeon all
while chatting about what makes these new-school

1176.text:
fishing gurus tick. Plus we head off to Woolastone
Court Trout Lakes where Hywel Morgan opens

1186.text:
We are back next week and if you're watching
YouTube please hit the subscribe button somewhere

1190.text:
on the outside of the screen or go to our
web page - f ieldsportschannel.tv where you

1194.text:
can click, to like us on facebook or follow
us on twitter. This has been Fieldsports Britain.

1199.text:
Good hunting, good shooting, good fishing,
and goodbye.
